comments.text:
+Marcus Nelson It's incorrect and spreads misinformation. It's a fallacy. 
Clearly you don't grasp that.
comments.author: Woodrow Feike

comments.text:
+PartiZAn18 Not necessarily . There is such a thing known as a tactical 
nuclear missle which can be mounted on stealth bombers.
comments.author: Rasta Toljin

comments.text:
+Woodrow Feike Nuke is used incorrectly as a replacement for bomb because 
nukes are considered the ultimate bomb. Saying nuked when you really just 
bombed something is using extreme emphasis. EMPHASIS!
comments.author: Marcus Nelson

comments.text:
+Marcus Nelson He said "I love the boomers and I love it when they reach 
the Hoover dam and nuke the other side of the dam ". Nukes weren't used. 
Just cause this is Fallout doesn't mean you can call everything a nuke.
comments.author: Woodrow Feike

comments.text:
+Woodrow Feike This is Fallout we're talking about. Nuclear explosions are 
a pretty common occurrence. Fat man nuke launchers, cars with nuclear 
engines, leftovers from the American stockpile, undetonated enemy 
warheads...have you even played the games? lol
comments.author: Marcus Nelson

comments.text:
+PartiZAn18 I'm aware, but when speaking casually, you wouldn't say "lets 
bomb them" when speaking about using nuclear weapons.
comments.author: Woodrow Feike

comments.text:
+Woodrow Feike  dude ... a nuke *is* a bomb. All nukes are bombs, not all 
bombs are nukes
comments.author: PartiZAn18

comments.text:
+Woodrow Feike Both fission and fusion nuclear weapons are considered to be 
bombs. Also, nuclear weapons can have a wide variety of yields. The 
smallest tactical nuclear weapon was the W54, designed to be used on the 
Davy Crockett launch system, and had a yield of 10 tons of TNT. The 
projectiles used in the portable Fat Man launchers would have an even 
smaller yield than that.
comments.author: Ego Simia

comments.text: Not if it is fat man nuke
comments.author: falloutnvspartan117

comments.text:
There might be a lot of different nukes but that's not the point. If they 
used a nuke it would've destroyed Hoover Dam making the entire war 
pointless. Know the difference between a bomb and a nuke. It'll make you 
look smarter.
comments.author: Woodrow Feike

comments.text: +ShadowCastPro you know there a lot of different nukes right
comments.author: falloutnvspartan117

comments.text:
+falloutnvspartan117 If they nuked the other side of the dam, depending on 
the nuke, the radius would most likely flatten the strip as well.
comments.author: ARandomShadow

comments.text: +Red Floyd bomb it nuke it whatever
comments.author: falloutnvspartan117

comments.text:
They didn't nuke it, they bombed it. Big difference.

One can completely destroy and pretty much disintegrate an entire city and 
leave radio-active fallout for the next 1000 years or more, the other is 
just a series of powerful explosions.
comments.author: Red Floyd

top_comment.text:
does anyone know how to get Fallout 3 to work on windows 7 ? all these lore 
videos really make me want to play it again yet it crashes all the time 
(cant even get out of the vault before it crashes). I have checked a few 
forums already but none of their solutions work.﻿
top_comment.author: MrTelboy

comments.text:
Its due to the fact that FO3 was designed to work on a Dual Core Processor, 
not a Quad Core that most have now... I had exactly the same problem on 
mine when I reinstalled it and had to change a parameter in some of the 
game files, limiting it to 2 cores
comments.author: primeattack

comments.text: +MrTelboy no problem good sir, enjoy.
comments.author: blaaah45

comments.text:
+blaaah45 thanks I got it working. I remember trying this before and it 
still crashing but for whatever reason it seems to work now. oh well back 
to exploring the wasteland.
comments.author: MrTelboy

comments.text:
+MrTelboy Try this: 
http://forums.steampowered.com/forums/showthread.php?t=2825612
It says its a fix to the title screen crash but it will also fix the ingame 
crashes as well. I am the film artist and editor for this series so I have 
to make sure my f03 is working at all times. It can get pretty tricky 
trying to run 50 mods all at the same time.
comments.author: blaaah45

comments.text:
+Ryan Reed I am subscribed to strife, never knew he made a video showing 
how to fix FO3. I will check it out thanks.
comments.author: MrTelboy

comments.text:
This is the main thing people have trouble with, how many cpu cores do you 
have? if more than two that is your best bet of the problem I suggest 
looking at William Strife (Yogscast Will) He has a full tutorial on how to 
fix these crashes. Hope his video explains and helps you.
comments.author: Ryan Reed

top_comment.text:
WELCOME to Season 2 of Fallout Lore!!! Our plan is to take this season to 
new heights with a whole new level of entertainment and polish. Our team 
has been breaking their backs to make this happen. Seriously, we haven't 
seen our families in weeks... and I think my goldfish died... Surely we 
think the effort has paid off though! Sadly, we did not reach our Patreon 
goal required to make this series a weekly one; however, we anticipate 
support will increase over time as we move forward. Meanwhile, we'll 
continue improving your viewing experience with what our generous donors 
have given, and we hope you'll enjoy the journey as we follow the 
Mysterious Storyteller through the wastes. Thanks again for watching, and 
for the love of Fallout, don't forget to whore this series out to all your 
friends!
Unlock the Fallout Lore Audio Book @ http://www.patreon.com/shoddycast
Follow us on Facebook @ http://Facebook.com/ShoddyCast
Follow us on Twitter @ http://twitter.com/ShoddyCast﻿
top_comment.author: ShoddyCast

top_comment.text:
Recently I helped the Boomers again and realized that I just handed them a 
bomber jet and they wanted to commit genocide on the entire wasteland with 
it. I'm a little concerned about that.﻿
top_comment.author: Ryuzaki Rue

comments.text:
+Robert Martinez Well, depending on who's still running the show in the 
Lucky 38 at the time. Robert House managed to shoot down ICBMs during the 
Great War. Surely he's got a few surface-to-air missiles hidden around 
Vegas, if someone could access and activate them.
comments.author: DeathKhan

comments.text:
+Robert Martinez The Boomers simply aren't as you characterize them.  They 
are isolationists (their interest is in defending their home), they are not 
at all aggressive. .  The Boomers have never attempted to destroy the 
ignorant savages of the wasteland, even though they've had good reason and 
ample means to do so for decades.  

As a tribal society led by elders, the Boomer's decision making system is 
more consensus based rather than hierarchy based. IE, Pearl and Loyal 
command "authority" only because they command the respect of the tribe. 
 What that means is that they act more as a moderating voice rather than a 
restraining one.  It's entirely possible that, in the fullness of time, 
voices advocating a more aggressive stance could come to the fore in Boomer 
society.  But that's possible with any faction or tribe.  

Based on their past history and current society though, if any faction in 
the Mojave can be trusted with more power, it's the Boomers.
comments.author: Jacob Harvell

comments.text:
+Jacob Harvell What you fail to see is that the only reason they have yet 
to do these things is because of Pearl and Loyal, two high ranking people 
in their society who are the only ones who keep the Boomers in check and 
will eventually die. Once they die there will not be anyone with enough 
authority to keep them reined in. Then they will start bombing anyone and 
anything they deem as ignorant savages regardless of whether or not the 
people are just civilians, soldiers, or bandits.
comments.author: Robert Martinez

comments.text:
+Ryuzaki Rue The Boomers have never been aggressive towards any other 
faction large or small.  The Boomers were in Nellis before either the NCR 
or the Legion even came to the Mojave.  They didn't attack "civilians" then 
either.  

And they could have done so with impunity.  Indirect fire artillery is 
already out of reach for anyone who doesn't have their own artillery or air 
support (that's kinda the point).

And when the Boomers were attacked by a truly genocidal faction, the NCR, 
their response was measured and reasonable.  If anything the Boomers were 
overly generous.

The Boomers are afraid of outsiders. Nothing more and nothing less.  But 
they have good reason to be given the neighborhood they live in.
comments.author: Jacob Harvell

comments.text:
+Jacob Harvell The reason they didn't is because, at least Pearl and Loyal, 
aren't stupid. A few howitzers does not mean they could win a war against 
NCR or even Legion. A bomber plane is different, because it can fly and is 
thus out of reach of most wasteland forces. They don't need to fear war 
nearly as much. Additionally once they can get one up and running, they 
could fix the other husks and have a bunch of planes functioning. Boomers 
do not want explosives to safeguard and hide them like the Brotherhood, 
they want to blow things up with them.
comments.author: Ryuzaki Rue

comments.text:
The Boomers had those howitzers for decades.  If they were at all like you 
characterize them, why didn't they use them to attack others rather than 
simply defend their home?

For the Boomers, having the bomber is the same as having the latest power 
armor is for the Brotherhood.  Something they believe will guarantee their 
continued armed superiority.  Nothing more.

The Boomer's only goal has always been to protect themselves from the 
ignorant savages of the wasteland. Who indeed VERY often are profoundly 
ignorant and extremely savage.  Even (especially) the "civilized" ones.

The only other major faction the Boomers have ever had problem with has 
been the NCR.  And it was the NCR who started that fight by trying to drive 
the Boomers out of Nellis wholesale.
comments.author: Jacob Harvell

comments.text:
+Jacob Harvell Being armed is all well and good. But as I said, they wanted 
to bomb innocent civilians for fun, because bombing an empty target wasn't 
interesting enough. A society like that is a problem to other societies. 
Fighting soldiers is war, killing civilians rather than soldiers is a war 
crime. Their goal isn't to have better armaments than everyone else, it is 
to use those armaments to bomb "ignorant savages".
comments.author: Ryuzaki Rue

comments.text:
The Boomer's way is to protect their community, nothing more.  They are 
simply more capable at this than most.
  
The Boomers actions have been reasoned and measured and limited.  They 
don't shell Vegas and they didn't retaliate when the NCR tried to wipe them 
out.  They are quite sane and not at all aggressive.  

The Boomers not only have advanced technology, but they use it to better 
the well-being of their entire tribe.  They are not barbarians.

The Boomer's assessment of outsiders as savages has been fair, justified 
and in accord with their experiences.      

And the Boomer's goal of having insurmountable armed superiority is a good 
goal for any tribe to have in a hostile land surrounded by hostile 
neighbors.  There's nothing wrong with that at all.
comments.author: Jacob Harvell

comments.text:
+Jacob Harvell Understanding them does not mean I have to condone them. I 
do understand the Boomers, as best I can understand a fictional group 
anyway. If their set of societal ideals  is to blow up everyone they deem 
savage then I think their society is insane, barbaric, and massively 
xenophobic. What one does is important, but remember that ones goals 
represents what they desire to do in the future. So I'm judging them on 
what they will do, given their way.
comments.author: Ryuzaki Rue

comments.text:
+Ryuzaki Rue In a military struggle, acknowledging that a force or faction 
would be an astounding asset if on your side, and a terrifying threat if on 
the enemy's is the very definition of respect.

Remember, the Boomers are a tribal society and many of them justifiably see 
the NCR as a group of hostile savages.  Hence their thought process goes 
something like this: "These NCR savages tried kill ALL of us, why should we 
feel the slightest compunction about killing ANY of them?"

That may not make them angels and saints by any means, but one should at 
least try to understand how people from different cultures think and view 
the world and look at what they actually DO instead of simply judging them 
as madmen just because their society has a different set of ideals from 
one's own.
comments.author: Jacob Harvell

comments.text:
+Jacob Harvell I wasn't talking solely about NCR although I might point out 
that if they are attacking NCR citizens and not just soldiers that is 
unjustified. It is fear, fear that if they do not have the Boomers on their 
side the Boomers will attack them. It is also tactical advantage, because 
having the Boomers, who have unique and destructive explosive capabilities, 
on your side is a great asset in a war.
comments.author: Ryuzaki Rue

comments.text:
+Ryuzaki Rue Nonsense.  Every major faction in the Mojave wants the Boomers 
on their side.  That's respect, not fear.  

Don't forget, the NCR actually tried to wipe out the inhabitants of Nellis. 
Far from being "innocent," The NCR's own actions have only justified the 
Boomer's view of outsiders.
comments.author: Jacob Harvell

comments.text:
+Jacob Harvell They demand fear, people don't know them enough to respect 
them. The self sufficient society is impressive, admittedly. I have not 
noticed respect for their neighbors. Pearl herself said her people wanted 
to attack a real target to distract the NCR from the Courier rising the 
Lady in the Lake, and she only said no to avoid war. The Boomers wanted to 
bomb real innocent people rather than an empty target for entertainment 
essentially.
comments.author: Ryuzaki Rue

comments.text:
+Ryuzaki Rue You should worry more about your definition of "gun nuts" than 
the Boomer's definition of anything.  Because the Boomers have not only 
earned what they have, they have used their power responsibly to build a 
thriving, self-sufficient community.  One that that not only demands 
respect but respects it's neighbors in turn.  

Of all the factions in the Mojave the Boomers are among the most admirable.
comments.author: Jacob Harvell

comments.text:
+Jacob Harvell I have difficulty trusting gun nuts who think it is their 
destiny to rain explosive ordinance on "ignorant savages". Also, what is 
there definition of "ignorant savages"?
comments.author: Ryuzaki Rue

comments.text:
If you want to know how the Boomers treat people who do them wrong, just 
look at how they treated the NCR.

When the NCR tried shut off the Boomer's water and really kill them all, 
what did the Boomers do?  
Did they wipe out NCR troops enmasse?  No. 
Did they target other random "savages"?  No.
Did they use their guns to save their community then let the NCR go about 
their business?  Yes, that's exactly what they did.

The Boomers are trustworthy.
comments.author: Jacob Harvell

comments.text:
+Jacob Harvell So raining bombs down on those who can not defend themselves 
and have done you no wrong is comparable to killing someone who just tried 
to kill you? I don't play a psychopath, I kill the people who try to kill 
me. I certainty don't rain bombs down on people who can't defend 
themselves. Legion is really the only people I'd consider bad enough for 
that.
comments.author: Ryuzaki Rue

comments.text:
What's wrong with that?  In case you didn't notice, most of the people in 
the wasteland ARE ignorant savages!  And wanting to rain high-explosive 
ordnance down on them from armored safety is far from unreasonable. 

How many "ignorant savages" did you rain a little death on between 
Goodsprings and Nellis?  

The Boomers have been responsible with the power they have.
comments.author: Jacob Harvell

comments.text:
+Jacob Harvell "To restore the bomber, to fly the open skies in armored 
safety, raining high-explosive ordnance upon ignorant savages - this is our 
destiny!" This is quoted directly from Pete, the Boomers historian.
comments.author: Ryuzaki Rue

comments.text:
The Boomer's violence isn't random.  If it were, they would have wiped out 
the rest of Vegas a long time ago.  Even without the bomber the Boomers 
have had the fire power to do so for quite some time.  And before the NCR 
and the Legion came into the region, no one could have stopped them.  

Since they found Nellis the Boomers only attack people who threaten their 
home.
comments.author: Jacob Harvell

pre-production since at least August 2010. However no announcement has been 
made as to any product being developed in the studio. But, Bethesda has sub 
forums that are dedicated to the discussion of Fallout 4. It's likely that 
Bethesda, or a partnered company similar to Obsidian, will be developing 
it, as they've stated that they have plans for the series. "The whole 
reason we went out and acquired the license and that we now own Fallout is 
that we clearly intended to make more than one." It'll happen. Just be 
patient.

top_comment.text:
nice episode, but i wonder what 'blitzkrieg' in english means. because in 
german a 'blitzkrieg' is a very fast attack, where you conquer a large 
ammount of the enemy's territory (blitz=lightning ... a metaphor you use 
for very high speed in german). it doesn't have anything to do with heavy 
weapons or artillery. usually you use light and mobile units, so you are 
faster. 'blitzkrieg' is the opposite of a static warfare, but the boomers 
stayed at the same place for years - which isn't a 'blitzkrieg' at all (at 
least by its german meaning).﻿
top_comment.author: montanus777

comments.text:
yes it is, but in fact 'blitzkrieg' isn't really a description for a whole 
war, but for a strategy during a specific battle or operation. e.g. the 
german army didn't use the blitzkrieg-strategy the whole WW2, but only for 
the invasion of france, poland and first in russia. after the german army 
got stuck in stalingrad, the blitzkrieg-strategy was over.
'blitzkrieg' was kind of a propaganda term. because in WW1 the french and 
the german army fought for years in a static warfare with millions of dead 
soldiers on both sides, but none of them could gain a victory over the 
other. the usage of the term 'blitzkrieg' was a way to express, that the 
germans didn't want to repeat this mistake.
comments.author: montanus777

comments.text: I'm pretty sure the translation is "lightning war".

comments.author: Goldfish Assassin

captions.text:
RobCo presents... Tomorrow's technology TODAY!
The world is a dull place, with billions of

boring people. Not you though! You're interesting!
You're special; a unique and beautiful snowflake!

Why deprive the world of your obvious genius?
We ALL should know what you’re doing, at

ALL TIMES. Whether you’re walking your dog
in the park, or enjoying a slice of cake.

Turn your obvious loneliness into somebody
else’s problem! Capture it all with the

latest in ego boosting technology. ED-NA!
The “eyebot”, “documentary”, “narrative”,

“assistant”. Gone are the days of privacy.
You’ll have privacy when you’re dead.

Share your life with your friends! Order yours
today! Our salesbots are standing by…

Now testing Eyebot Documentary Narrative Assistant.
Say hello ED-NA.

Begin recording ED-NA. You and I have a Wasteland
to explore.
Damn it. The red light isn’t on.

Oh, there isn't one. Well. Wasteland Survival
Guide; Volume One.

They say an armed society is a polite society.
If that's true, then Vault 34 had to be the

most polite place on Earth. Back in 2077 when
the bombs fell, the folks at Vault-tec wanted

to see what happens when far too many people
got squeezed into tight quarters with way

too many guns. Vault 34 was the petri dish
for that little experiment and, after keeping

people cooped up in there for a century, the
place turned into powder keg of paranoia,
over-population, and high-explosive etiquette.

I'm outside the entrance to the vault. It's
a ways East of New Vegas, in an inhospitable

spot in the hills. Has a truckload of atomic
waste parked right in front, and the only
thing that dares to come near are the geckos.
They won’t be a problem though.

The radiation levels are lethal inside and
out, so virtually no one has ventured inside

and the last people to leave did so over fifty
years ago.

Inside the vault is nothing but feral ghouls
and radioactive water. Most of the computer

records are damaged, but before the Overseer
ghoulified, he left behind written journals

of what happened. Vault 34 seemed like it
would be a great place to wait out the apocalypse;

Vault-tec had equipped it with extravagant
recreational and fitness centers. Much more

elaborate than other vaults. But making room
for that full-sized swimming pool meant removing
some of the living quarters.

Every Vault came with a small stockpile of
weapons for a security team. They had to keep

the peace among a thousand people who were
cooped up together for anywhere from ten to

two-hundred years. Most of them only had a
handful of small arms, but Vault 34 got the

sort of arsenal that could have turned the
tide at the Battle of Anchorage. Grenade launchers,

missiles, prototype energy weapons – not
the sort of thing you'd want to use in the

confined space of a vault – and nary a lock
in sight.

The Overseers knew that a thousand people
armed with 40 millimeter peacemakers wasn't

a good idea, so they figured out how to lock
it up and keep it under guard, but that only

kept the peace for a few generations. Eventually
the overcrowding became so great that a group

of vault dwellers stormed the armory, stole
most of the bigger guns and headed out into
the Mojave.

Folks around the Mojave called them the Boomers,
and it ain't hard to see why. They emerged

from Vault 34 with stars in their eyes and
missile launchers on their shoulders around

2231. After blowing up every tribe they came
across, they eventually discovered Nellis

Airforce Base to the East. None of the pre-war
aircraft were still functional, but the Boomers

found records on other nearby military bases
and soon enough they had added giant guns

called “Howitzers” to their collection,
hauled all the way from the Hawthorne Army

Depot in Arizona. They had stockpiled enough
ordnance to level a town several times over

– and anyone dumb enough to set foot in
it for the next fifty years.

The 
rare person who can observe the patterns in
their Blitzkrieg and move fast enough to make

it inside the base will find Nellis to be
one of the garden spots of the Mojave. They

pipe in fresh water from Lake Mead, they grow
their own crops, and have a set of solar panels

that give them electricity without having
to worry about who's controlling the Hoover Dam.

They have a museum dedicated to their history,
and a tyke who's happy to tell it to anyone

who'll listen to the whole story. And if the
child's cave painting isn't detailed enough,

their leader is a woman who was born inside
the vault, and remembers the whole thing firsthand.

She's done right by her people for the last
fifty years, and was probably quite the looker

in her day. Despite Mother Pearl's guidance,
the Boomers are still some of the most xenophobic

people in the Wasteland, convinced that it's
their destiny to blow up all of us savages

once they get a bomber flying. They have a
plan that they don't like to discuss with

outsiders, but if you earn the trust of the
old timers they’ll talk about a “Lady

of the Lake”. It might be that they have
some superstition about that rusty pre-war

bomber that's sitting at the bottom of Lake
Meade...

So far the Boomers have done well with their
isolationism, but their resources are still

limited, and much like the Brotherhood of
Steel, they may face only a slow death should
their population and ammo dwindle.

The people who stayed behind back in Vault
34, learned their own lesson about isolationism.

Their Overseers refused to let anyone leave,
and the many attempts to revolt eventually

resulted in the Vault's reactor malfunctioning,
and that swimming pool flooding most of the

place, trapping them all inside a radioactive
swamp.

The remnants of their vast arsenal await anyone
brave enough to wade through the radioactive

waters, and fight past the feral ghouls. It's
an enticing treasure trove for prospectors

who have plenty of Rad-X stockpiled, and who
need to compensate for something.

Too many people these days are concerned with
blowing things up. Few folks wonder how it

all got built in the first place. Those airplanes,
the hangars, the Vaults. All were made with

steel. In the old days they dug their iron
from deep within the Earth. Refined it into

steel in huge mills unlike anything still
standing in New California, and used it to

make the steel girders that held up the old
world.

Today there's only one place that can still
do that. It's hard labor, and the people who

do it aren't exactly there for the satisfaction
of an honest day's. But that-
is a story for another day.
